Graphical abstract A series of Cu/TiO2 catalysts was successfully synthesized by ice melting method for the first time, and their performance for the selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 was evaluated. The catalyst with Cu/Ti molar ratio of 0.005 exhibited excellent catalytic performance at low temperature. Compared with the traditional co-precipitation method (Cu0.005Ti-Con), the NOx conversion (at 285 °C) and N2 selectivity (at 240 °C) of Cu/TiO2 synthesized by ice melting (named as Cu0.005Ti-Ice) increased by 30 % and 10 %, respectively. Characterization results revealed that Cu0.005Ti-Ice exhibited outstanding physicochemical properties, including smaller grain size of particles, the well dispersion and high surface atomic concentration of Cu species, enrichment of Cu2+ species (34.54 %) and chemical absorbed oxygen species (19.96 %), and excellent redox capacity and acidity. These conditions provided the CuTi-Ice catalysts with enhanced deNOx performance at low temperature. Additionally, the inhibition of the non-selective catalytic reduction and NH3 catalytic oxidation on Cu0.005Ti-Ice catalysts reduced N2O and NO2 concentration, resulting in outstanding SCR activity at low temperature. Keywords Ice melting method Co-precipitation method Low temperature SCR deNOxCu/TiO2catalyst 1 Introduction The preparation method, a part of the process in obtaining a catalyst, has an important effect on the structure and performance of catalysts. Scholars around the world have extensively studied preparation methods of catalysts and attempted to improve their performance to adapt their applications in various fields. Wei et al. provided a new strategy that combines ice melting and photochemical reduction method to deposit Pt atoms on various substrates, including titanium dioxide nanoparticles, graphene and mesoporous carbon [1]. In comparison with commercial Pt/C catalyst, the Pt/C catalyst synthesized by ice melting and photochemical reduction method shows superior catalytic activity in the electrochemical hydrogen evolution reaction. The ice melting method may have broad applicability for the green synthesis of catalytic materials. Based on the co-precipitation method, Wei et al. also mixed AgNO3 precursor solution into NaBH4 solution by ice melting method [2]. The atomically dispersed metals were successfully synthesized by controlling the reaction kinetics and thermodynamics. The nucleation and solid growth could be efficiently prevented. However, the ice melting method may not be applicable in some fields. At present, the successful application of ice melting method is mainly limited in the area of noble metals or single atoms and has never been applied to transition metal oxide catalysts successfully. Environmental catalysis is an important branch in the field of catalysis. Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) technology is a hotspot in the field of environmental catalysis due to its highly efficient NOx removal ability and widely used in waste incinerators, industrial boilers as well as biomass fuel power plants. The V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 are common catalyst and have good catalytic activity at a relatively high temperature of 300 °C–420 °C in SCR reaction [3,4]. However, these catalysts are limited by the narrow operating temperature window [5], poor N2 selectivity [6] and toxicity of V2O5 [7]. Hence, researchers have focused on non-vanadium catalysts in recent years and studied a series of catalysts, including Mn [8–10], Ce [11–13] and Cu [14,15]. Among them, Cu-based catalysts have become a key research target in SCR reaction due to their low cost, non-toxicity, and excellent catalytic performance [16]. However, the catalytic performance at low temperature and N2 selectivity of Cu-based catalysts still need to be further improved. The catalytic performance of Cu-based catalysts is related to the preparation method. Cu-based catalysts can be prepared via sol-gel [17–19], impregnation [14,20,21], co-precipitation [22–24] and ion-exchange [25–27] methods and their catalytic performance were shown in Table 1 . Among them, Jiang et al. investigated the influence of ion-exchange method (ION-F) and one-pot method (ONE-F) on the catalytic properties of Cu/SSZ-13 catalyst [26]. They found that ONE-F exhibited better SCR performance than ION-F below 400 °C due to its smaller particle size and more uniformly distributed active sites. Deka et al. prepared Cu-CHA catalysts via three different methods, including aqueous or vapor phase post-synthetic treatment and direct synthesis of Cu-loaded SAPO-34 [28]. The results showed that the catalysts prepared via wet chemical routes had excellent deNOx activity and high N2 selectivity compared with those prepared via chemical vapor deposition. The proper catalyst preparation method is of great significance for improving catalytic performance. In this study, Cu/TiO2 catalysts were synthesized by ice melting method for the first time, and their performance for the SCR of NO with NH3 was evaluated to improve the catalyst structure and performance. For comparison, Cu/TiO2 catalyst was also prepared by traditional co-precipitation method. A series of characterization methods, including X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) calculation, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), temperature-programmed reduction with H2 (H2-TPR) and temperature-programmed desorption with NH3 (NH3-TPD), was conducted to evaluate the influence of preparation methods on the structure and performance of catalysts and develop a new approach for the development of efficient catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation As shown in Fig. 1 , in this study, Cu/TiO2 catalysts were prepared by ice melting method using cupric nitrate as precursor and Degussa TiO2 as support. First, a certain amount of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O dissolved in deionized water was frozen to form the ice cube. Then, TiO2 was added into saturated oxalic acid solution, and the turbid fluid was formed. Finally, the ice cube was dissolved in turbid fluid with magnetic stirring at −4 °C for approximately 3 h. After drying at 110 °C for 12 h, the sample was calcined at 500 °C for 3 h. For comparison, Cu/TiO2 sample was also prepared by traditional co-precipitation method. A certain amount of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O dissolved in deionized water was added into TiO2 dissolved in saturated oxalic acid solution. The same steps above were followed. Finally, all samples were crushed and sieved using a 40–60 mesh sieve for activity measurement. The samples synthesized by ice melting and co-precipitation method were denoted as CuxTi-Ice and CuxTi-Con, respectively, where x indicates the Cu/Ti molar ratio and Ice and Con represent ice melting and co-precipitation methods, respectively. The V2O5(1%)-WO3(9%)/TiO2 catalyst was prepared according to Refs [29]. 2.2 Catalytic activity measurement The NH3-SCR activity, N2O concentration,independent NH3 and NO oxidation experiment were carried out on a fixed bed reactor (i.d. = 1 cm) to evaluate the catalytic performance using 2.3 mL catalysts (40–60 meshes) without any pre-treatment (As shown in Fig. 2 ). The reaction conditions were as follows: 700 ppm NO (when used), 700 ppm NH3 (when used), and 3.5 % O2 and N2 in balance with gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 50,000 h−1 for this system. The inlet and outlet NOx concentrations of reactants and products were measured using an NOx analyzer (ECOMD, rbr Messtechnik GmbH, Germany). The N2O concentrations were analyzed using an N2O analyzer (G200, Geotechnical Instruments Ltd, UK). The NH3 concentrations were detected by a FT-IR gas analyzer (Gasmet DX-4000, Temet Instrument Oy, Finland). The conversion of NOx in SCR reaction was calculated as follows: (1) NOx conversion (%) = 100 % × (CNOx(in)-CNOx(out))/CNOx(in) N2 selectivity was calculated as follows: (2) N 2 s e l e c t i v i t y (%) = 100 % × [ 1 − 2 C N 2 O ( o u t ) / ( C N O x ( i n ) + C N H 3 ( i n ) − C N O x ( o u t ) − C N H 3 ( o u t ) ) ] The kinetic parameter was calculated to elaborate the surface reaction. We assumed that the first order of the reaction depends on NO, whereas the zero order depends on NH3. The catalyst activity constant was calculated based on NOx conversion by the following equations [30]: (3) k = -V·ln(1-x)/M (4) k = A·exp (-Ea/RT) where k represents the catalyst activity constant (mL·g−1·s−1), V is the gas flow rate (mL·s−1), M is the weight of catalyst (g), x is the NOx conversion (%), A is the pre-exponential factor, Ea is the apparent activation energy (kJ·mol−1), R refers to the gas constant (8.314 J·mol−1 ·K−1), and T is the reaction temperature (K). 2.3 Catalyst characterization The BET specific surface area (SBET) was determined via a multipoint BET method using the adsorption data in the relative pressure (P/P0) range of 0.05−0.30. The pore size distributions were calculated by employing the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda model on ASAP 2020 (Micromeritics Corporation, Atlanta, GA, USA). The samples were pretreated for 4 h under vacuum conditions at 400 °C to purify the surface before measurements. The micrograph structures of the samples were observed by SEM on a FEI XL30 ESEM (FEI Inc. Phillips, Hillsboro, OR, USA), and the morphology of the samples was detected by TEM (JEM-2010, JEOL Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) at an energy of 200 eV. XRD patterns were recorded on an X-ray diffractometer (model D/max RA, Rigaku Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) with Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.15418 nm) to investigate the crystal phases of the samples, and the information was obtained with scattering angles (2θ) ranging from 10° to 80° at a step rate of 10° min−1 with a step size of 0.02. XPS was carried out on an ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, USA) with Al Ka radiation (hv = 1486.6 eV, λ = 500 μm) operated at 150 W to investigate the chemical valence state distribution and the proportions of surface elements. The spectra were recorded in the fixed analyzer transmission mode at an energy of 20 eV. The C 1s line at 284.8 eV from carbon impurities was chosen as reference to detect the binding energies of all the elements. The reducibility and acidity of the samples were reflected by H2-TPR and NH3-TPD experiments on TP-5080 setup (Tianjin Xianquan Industry and Trade Development Co. Ltd., China) and MicroActive for autoChem II 2920 (Micromeritics Corporation, Atlanta, GA, USA), respectively. For H2-TPR, the samples were pre-treated at 200 °C for 1 h in pure N2 before experiments and then cooled down to 70 °C. Then, 10 % H2/N2 were introduced with a heating rate of 10 °C/min from 70 °C to 800 °C. Prior to NH3-TPD experiments, the samples were purified at 200 °C for 1 h in He and then saturated with 5% NH3/He at room temperature. The desorption information was collected by increasing the temperature from 50 °C to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization 3.1.1 XRD and BET analysis The XRD patterns were determined to explore the crystal structure of Cu0.005Ti-Con and Cu0.005Ti-Ice samples, and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . Cu nanoparticles were not detected in both XRD patterns and may exist in an amorphous form or some small Cu clusters [31,32]. For both samples, the anatase phase was the main crystal phase (PDF#21-2172), and other peaks belonged to the rutile phase (PDF#21-2176). We could notice that the diffraction peak intensity of TiO2 at 25.57°, 54.22° and 62.38° on Cu0.005Ti-Ice were weaker than those on Cu0.005Ti-Con, indicating the decrease in crystallinity and the increased interaction between Cu and Ti species on Cu0.005Ti-Ice sample. According to the XRD patterns, the crystallite sizes at different degrees were also calculated by the Scherrer equation and shown in Table 2 . The results showed the difference of TiO2 crystallite size between Cu0.005Ti-Con and Cu0.005Ti-Ice sample. It was worth noting the TiO2 crystallite size of Cu0.005Ti-Con at 38.83° and 62.38° were 35.93 nm and 26.29 nm, respectively, about two times of Cu0.005Ti-Ice sample. The ice melting method had influence on the growth of catalyst grain. N2 sorption isotherms of Cu0.005Ti-Con and Cu0.005Ti-Ice samples were examined to investigate the pore structure of catalysts. In Fig. 4 (a), the adsorption-desorption isotherms of both catalysts belonged to type IV isotherms with type H1 hysteresis loops according to IUPAC and they correspond to the mesoporous nanostructures of both catalysts [21,33]. The distribution of pore diameter shown in Fig. 4(b) suggested that almost all the pore diameters of Cu0.005Ti-Con were 30 nm, whereas Cu0.005Ti-Ice sample has more mesoporous at 2 nm and less mesoporous at 30 nm. The high dispersion of Cu species covered the pore of TiO2 support and led to the decrease of pore size of Cu0.005Ti-Ice. Table 3 showed that the BET surface area and pore volume of CuTi-Ice and CuTi-Con samples were similar and not influenced by the synthesized method. The Cu0.005Ti-Ice samples have larger BET surface area and pore volume than P25 TiO2 and they would provide more interface for SCR reaction after Cu loading. 3.1.2 SEM, TEM and EDS mappings The SEM images of both samples are shown in Fig. 5 . It could be observed that there were some white aggregates with different shapes and sizes on Cu0.005Ti-con sample, which may be formed by the precipitates that were not uniformly supported on TiO2 in the liquid-phase reaction process. The EDS mapping results of Ti, O and Cu elements on both samples are also displayed. Clearly, Ti and O elements on both samples were uniform. Based on the comparison of Cu species on different samples, as shown in Fig. 5(a), Cu species were relatively well dispersed on the surface of Cu0.005Ti-Ice with much more uniform state. By contrast, a rich region covered with Cu species was observed in the local area of Cu0.005Ti-Con in Fig. 5(b). The microstructures of samples were recorded by TEM and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . As shown in Fig. 6(a, c) and (b, d), the samples were in the form of oval-shaped anatase crystal particles. Some particles were aggregated on Cu0.005Ti-Con as shown in Fig. 6(d), whereas the particles on Cu0.005Ti-Ice were more scattered as shown in Fig. 6(c). The lattice fringes of different samples were also measured and marked in Fig. 6(e) and (f). For Cu0.005Ti-Con, the lattice fringes of 0.352 and 0.332 nm belonged to anatase (101) and rutile (110), respectively. For Cu0.005Ti-Ice, the lattice fringes of 0.351, 0.243 and 0.335 nm matched anatase (101), anatase (103) and rutile (110), respectively, wherein some smaller lattice fringes of TiO2 emerged. No plane ascribed to Cu oxides could be detected in TEM micrographs, which agreed with the XRD result. 3.1.3 XPS analysis XPS was used to detect the surface chemical valence of the catalyst, and Ti 2p spectra are shown in Fig. 7 (a). The peaks at 458.8 eV and 464.5 eV belonged to Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2, respectively, indicating that Ti species were mainly present in the state of Ti4+ in both catalysts [34,35]. Compared with Cu0.005Ti-Con, the binding energy did not move on Cu0.005Ti-Ice, indicating that the synthesis method of catalysts had little effect on the state of Ti species. XPS analysis was further investigated in the following. The O 1s XPS spectra are depicted in Fig. 7(b). For both catalysts, the main peak at binding energy of 528.3–533.4 eV could be divided into two peaks: one peak at 528.3–530.5 eV belonged to the lattice oxygen (denoted as Oα), and the other peak at 530.5–533.4 eV can be attributed to the chemical absorbed oxygen (denoted as Oβ) [24,36]. The individual peak areas were used to calculate Oβ/(Oβ+Oα), and the ratios are shown in Table 4 . The ratio of Oβ over Cu0.005Ti-Con was 14.75 %, whereas that of Oβ over Cu0.005Ti-Ice was 19.69 %, which is higher than that in Cu0.005Ti-Con. Oβ always plays an important part in SCR reaction and facilitates “fast SCR” process [37]. The presence of higher oxygen defects and oxygen mobility could attribute to the improved catalytic activity of catalysts at relative low temperatures. The Cu 2p XPS spectra are shown in Fig. 7(c). For both catalysts, the binding energy at 933 eV can be attributed to Cu 2p3/2 peaks belonging to Cu2+ species. The binding energy at 932 eV and 952 eV can be attributed to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 peaks, respectively, which can be ascribed to Cu+ species. The shake-up peak at 938−945 eV can be attributed to Cu2+ species [38–40]. Both Cu+ and Cu2+ species were found in catalysts and the ratios of Cu2+/(Cu2++Cu+) are shown in Table 4. The ratio of Cu2+/(Cu2++Cu+) in Cu0.005Ti-Ice was 34.54 %, which is higher than that in Cu0.005Ti-Con (28.57 %), indicating that the active Cu2+ species increased significantly by ice melting method during catalyst preparation. The active Cu2+ species was conducive to the oxidation of NO to NO2 to promote the “fast SCR” during the reaction [21,41], which facilitated the enhancement of catalytic performance and was beneficial to the Cu2+/Cu+ redox cycle at low temperatures in SCR reaction [42]. The increase of active Cu2+ species may improve the catalytic activity of the Cu0.005Ti-Ice sample. To obtain further information, the elemental compositions of different samples were listed in Table 4. The main components of Cu/TiO2 catalyst were CuO and TiO2. XRF results showed the contents of CuO in Cu0.005Ti-Ice and Cu0.005Ti-Con almost remained consistent, they were 0.47 % and 0.49 %, respectively. XPS and EDS results were used to represent the surface and the overall state of the samples. Cu0.005Ti-Ice and Cu0.005Ti-Con samples exhibited similar Cu/Ti atomic ratios, while the concentration of Cu species on Cu0.005Ti-Ice determined by XPS was higher than that from EDS, indicating the well distribution of Cu species on the surface of Cu0.005Ti-Ice. 3.1.4 H2-TPR analysis H2-TPR experiment was used to investigate the redox property of active phase in catalysts. The H2-TPR profiles of Cu0.005Ti-Con and Cu0.005Ti-Ice samples are shown in Fig. 8 . The main reduction process of Cu species is Cu2+→ Cu+→ Cu, and the second step usually occurs over 800 °C [21,43]. In this study, all reaction peaks that appeared on the samples were considered as the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+. By combining the XRD and XPS results, a sequence of reduction peak appeared at 205 °C, 223 °C, and 320 °C in Cu0.005Ti-Ice, which could be ascribed to the reduction of highly dispersed CuO species on TiO2 support, the reduction of small and dispersed oxide clusters not forming crystallites yet, and the reduction of oxygen on the support surface and the interaction between CuO and TiO2 [18,44]. By contrast, only two peaks were detected in Cu0.005Ti-Con. The first reduction peaks of Cu2+ shifted from 237 °C to 205 °C, indicating that Cu0.005Ti-Ice was more prone to redox reaction. Meanwhile, the H2 consumption of samples was calculated on the basis of the reduction peak areas. The three peak area ratios in Cu0.005Ti-Ice were 8%, 35% and 57%, whereas the two peak area ratios in Cu0.005Ti-Con were 47 % and 53 %, suggesting the existence of highly dispersed CuO species in Cu0.005Ti-Ice. This result agrees with the XRD and EDS results. The well dispersion of active Cu species could enhance the redox property and oxygen storage. 3.1.5 NH3-TPD analysis The adsorption of NH3 on catalyst surface is a significant factor in SCR. NH3-TPD experiment was used to investigate the surface acidity of catalyst as it can reflect the strength and quantity of acid sites over the catalysts based on the position and area of the peaks. As presented in Fig. 9 , three peaks were found on both catalysts at 100 °C–500 °C. For both catalysts, desorption peaks detected at 80−215 °C could be assigned to the NH4 + from weak Brønsted acid sites [36], whereas peaks at 300 °C–450 °C corresponded to chemisorbed NH3 species from strong Brønsted acid sites and Lewis strong acid sites [14,41]. Notably, all the peaks on Cu0.005Ti-Ice shifted to higher temperatures than Cu0.005Ti-Con, indicating that the strength of acid sites was increased. The area of chemically adsorbed NH3 species on samples were integrated from 75 °C to 700 °C, and Cu0.005Ti-Ice and Cu0.005Ti-Con had areas of 7.84 and 7.23, respectively. Fig. 9 shows that the acid amount from Lewis acid sites in Cu0.005Ti-Ice decreased. Hence, Cu0.005Ti-Ice generated more acids from Brønsted acid sites, which may be attributed to its improved SCR performance at low temperature. 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Catalytic activity Fig. 10 (a) and Figure S1 present the influences of Cu/Ti molar ratio over two different preparation methods on the de-NOx activity. As shown in Fig. 10(a), CuxTi samples showed different catalytic performances at 285 °C in SCR reaction. For further details, Fig. 10(b) presents the catalytic activity of Cu0.005Ti and V2O5-WO3/TiO2 samples in the whole temperature range. For Cu0.005Ti-Ice samples, over 90 % NOx conversion could be obtained at 300 °C, whereas only approximately 80 % NOx conversion could be achieved on Cu0.005Ti-Con and V2O5-WO3/TiO2 samples during the whole reaction temperature. Especially for the working temperature at 285 °C, Cu0.005Ti-Ice showed better NOx conversion over 90 %, which is about 30 % over Cu0.005Ti-Con (65 %) and 3 times higher than V2O5-WO3/TiO2 (30 %), exhibiting superior deNOx performance at the working temperatures set. The samples synthesized by ice melting method generated beneficial experimental effects in SCR reaction and the results are well matched with the XPS and H2-TPR results. N2 selectivity was tested and the results are shown in Fig. 10(c). The Cu0.005Ti-Ice maintained N2 selectivity of over 90 % below 240 °C and exhibited ∼10 % higher N2 selectivity than Cu0.005Ti-Con. Thus, the N2O concentration of both catalysts was also tested in NH3 oxidation reaction to evaluate the extent of partial oxidation of NH3 at elevated temperature. As shown in Fig. 10(d), at the beginning, the N2O concentration could be ignored below 200 °C. When the temperature exceeded 250 °C, the N2O concentration increased gradually in SCR and NH3 oxidation reactions, and the Cu0.005Ti-Con showed much higher N2O concentration than Cu0.005Ti-Ice at low temperature. Notably, the N2O concentration in SCR reaction was higher than that in NH3 oxidation reaction. Especially for the Cu0.005Ti-Con catalyst, the N2O concentration in the SCR reaction increased rapidly, suggesting that most by-product N2O was produced from the non-selective oxidation between NH3 and O2. Meanwhile, in addition to the formation of N2O in products, the NO2 concentration could also be detected when the working temperature above 300 °C. As shown in Fig. 10(e), at the beginning, no NO2 concentration could be detected on both samples below 300 °C. However, the NO2 concentration increased gradually when the temperature above 300 °C. A large amount of NO2 concentration could be found on Cu0.005Ti-Con sample and approximately 80 ppm NO2 concentration produced at 375 °C. The formation of NO2 came from the over oxidation of NH3 in the presence of high oxygen concentration, which also led to the decrease of N2 selectivity. For Cu0.005Ti-Ice sample, both the undesired N2O and NO2 product were suppressed, leading to the high N2 selectivity. The NO oxidation reaction was also tested and results were shown in Fig. 10(f). At first, the NO oxidation reaction had little activity below 150 ℃ for both catalysts. Then the NO conversion increased gradually when the temperature reached 200 ℃, but the NO oxidation activity of Cu0.005-Con was quite low and the NO conversion was only 2.4 % at 250 ℃. It was worth noting the NO oxidation activity of Cu0.005-Ice was always higher than that of Cu0.005-Con, especially for the temperature range from 200 ℃ to 300 ℃. During the NH3-SCR reaction, the oxidation of NO to NO2 through fast SCR reaction route can improve the catalytic activity of catalysts, especially conducive to the improvement of catalytic activity at low temperature [18,45]. The effect of GHSV tolerance on Cu0.005Ti-Ice sample was presented in Fig. S2. The activity temperature window was similar when the GHSV increased from 30,000 h−1 to 100,000 h−1. However, the catalytic activity shifted to lower temperatures at GHSV of 70,000 and 100,000 h−1. The NOx conversion at GHSV of 70,000 and 100,000 h−1 was approximately 20 % higher than that of 30,000 and 50,000 h−1, suggesting that the increase of GHSV can improve the catalytic activity of Cu0.005Ti-Ice to some extent. The enhanced catalytic performance attributed to the property of samples, including the regular growth of particles and the dispersion degree of active components on the support, and we inferred that the limitations from the mass transfer of particles on sample slightly affected its activity performance [46]. The uncertainty analysis of this study comes from several aspects: (1) Before the catalyst preparation, the process of reading the values of scales and beakers during the weighing process could introduce uncertainty; (2) In the process of catalyst preparation, the preparation and molding of multi-batches of catalysts and the water absorption in the process of catalyst storage could introduce uncertainty; (3) During the activity test, the reading of values from flue gas analyzer are greatly affected by human factors and the fluctuation of numbers resulted in the deviation of the experimental values. 3.2.2 NH3-SCR kinetic study NH3-SCR kinetic reaction was studied. In Fig. 11 (a), during the temperature range from 125 °C to 300 °C, the catalyst activity constant on Cu0.005Ti-Ice was always higher than that on Cu0.005Ti-Con and reached the maximum of 59.8 mL g−1·s−1. Surprisingly, when the temperature reached 300 °C, the activity constant on Cu0.005Ti-Ice was approximately thrice that of Cu0.005Ti-Con and exhibited significant improvement for the removal of NOx. Meanwhile, the pre-exponential factor and apparent activation energy were calculated using the Arrhenius equation. As shown in Fig. 11(b), Cu0.005Ti-Ice sample showed the higher Ea (33.6 kJ mol-1) than Cu0.005Ti-Con (16.8 kJ mol-1), suggesting that the limitation originating from the mass transfer between particles was somewhat reduced and had less effect on Cu0.005Ti-Ice sample [18,25,26], which may be attributed to the smaller crystallite sizes as well as uniformly distribution of Cu species. Meanwhile, Cu0.005Ti-Ice had higher lnA (9.3) than Cu0.005Ti-Con (4.8). The higher the pre-exponential factor, the higher the frequency of active Cu species collision [26], resulting in the remarkable deNOx performance on Cu0.005Ti-Ice at low temperature. 3.3 Possible mechanism of synthesized promotional effect The Cu0.005Ti-Ice catalyst was synthesized by ice melting method, which is a new method that involves freezing the precursor and melting it into support solution at approximately −4 °C. This process is a new strategy to control and release reactants in ultra-slow reaction rate. The way the reactants enter the solution directly affects the release concentration and reaction kinetics of the reactants. The slower the release rate is, the lower the concentration will be, which can effectively prevent the nucleation and aggregation of metal oxides. For Cu0.005Ti-Ice sample synthesized by ice melting method, the precursor solution in the form of frozen reacts with the precipitant solution at an extremely low speed and low concentration to achieve high dispersion on the TiO2 support, which can effectively prevent the aggregation and growth of solids, leading to its smaller grain size of particles and more uniformly distributed Cu species, contributing to the less limitation originating from the mass transfer between particles. According to SEM, TEM and EDS mapping results, Cu species were highly dispersed along with higher surface atomic concentration on Cu0.005Ti-Ice. The ice melting method effectively controlled the process of metal oxide particle aggregation and solid growth and may form some atomically dispersed metals [2]. The enhanced quantity of active species is demonstrated by XPS results. Cu0.005Ti-Ice showed a higher ratio of Oβ/(Oβ+Oα) and Cu2+/(Cu2++Cu+) (19.96 % and 34.54 %, respectively) than Cu0.005Ti-Con. Chemical absorbed oxygen Oβ has high mobility and plays an active role in promoting the reaction process. The active species of Cu2+ was conducive to the oxidation of NO to NO2 to propel the “fast SCR” at low temperatures in SCR reaction [41]. Combined with XPS and H2-TPR results, the reduction peaks of Cu2+ shifted to lower temperature and became prone to redox reaction due to the increased active species. Hence, the deNOx performance of Cu0.005Ti-Ice was significantly enhanced. The possible mechanism was investigated to illustrate the promotional effect of catalytic performance on samples synthesized by ice melting method. In this reaction, both E-R and L-H mechanisms were performed similar to other mechanisms of NH3-SCR [24,36,47,48], and the latter one may dominate the improvement of the reaction process [49]. The L-H mechanism in this study was described by Eqs. (5–10) [24,50,51], and the schematic diagram is shown in Fig. 12 . The enhanced catalytic performance of Cu0.005Ti-Ice could be contributed to the formation of more adsorbed NH3 and adsorbed NOx species. Initially, the abundant chemical adsorbed oxygen species in Cu0.005Ti-Ice promoted the adsorption and activation of NO to form adsorbed NO2. Then, the adsorbed NH4 + species could react with adsorbed NO2 to form NH4NO2, and NH4NO2 could decompose to N2 and H2O at low temperature, which is an essential step in SCR [47]. The adsorbed NH3 species produced by the abundant active Cu2+ species [52,53] could be adsorbed on catalyst and react with adsorbed NO2 by “fast SCR” reaction. Finally, the final products N2 and H2O, were produced and achieved the enhanced deNOx effect. (5) O2 (g) → 2O− (6) NO (g) + O− → NO2 (a) (7) NH3 (g) → NH3 (a) (8) NH3 (g) → NH4 + (a) (9) NH4 + (a) + e− + NO2 (a) → NH4NO2 (a) →N2 + H2O (Brønsted acid sites) (10) NH3 (a) + NO2 (a) + NO (g) → N2 + H2O (Lewis acid sites) 4 Conclusions In this work, a Cu/TiO2 catalyst was successfully synthesized by ice melting method and used for selective reduction of NO by NH3. In comparison with Cu0.005Ti-Con, Cu0.005Ti-Ice sample (Cu/Ti molar ratio = 0.005) could effectively enhance the catalytic activity with the improvement of N2 selectivity at low temperature in NH3-SCR reaction. By using SEM, TEM, BET, XPS, H2-TPR and NH3-TPD characterizations, the results revealed that the Cu0.005Ti-Ice catalyst with smaller grain size of particles exhibited well dispersion and higher surface atomic concentration of Cu species, avoiding the aggregation of particles and increasing crystallinity. The active species, including Cu2+ species and chemical absorbed oxygen were enhanced, which promoted the oxidation process of NO to NO2. Meanwhile, the redox property and acid amount were enhanced at low temperature. The inhibition of the non-selective catalytic reduction and NH3 catalytic oxidation on Cu0.005Ti-Ice catalysts reduced N2O and NO2 concentration, resulting in outstanding SCR activity at low temperature. The reaction mainly followed L-H mechanism. The results could provide a new strategy for the preparation of highly efficient deNOx catalysts used for NH3-SCR reaction. coredata.dc:description: A series of Cu/TiO2 catalysts was successfully synthesized by ice melting method for the first time, and their performance for the selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 was evaluated. The catalyst with Cu/Ti molar ratio of 0.005 exhibited excellent catalytic performance at low temperature. Compared with the traditional co-precipitation method (Cu0.005Ti-Con), the NOx conversion (at 285 °C) and N2 selectivity (at 240 °C) of Cu/TiO2 synthesized by ice melting (named as Cu0.005Ti-Ice) increased by 30 % and 10 %, respectively. Characterization results revealed that Cu0.005Ti-Ice exhibited outstanding physicochemical properties, including smaller grain size of particles, the well dispersion and high surface atomic concentration of Cu species, enrichment of Cu2+ species (34.54 %) and chemical absorbed oxygen species (19.96 %), and excellent redox capacity and acidity. These conditions provided the CuTi-Ice catalysts with enhanced deNOx performance at low temperature. Additionally, the inhibition of the non-selective catalytic reduction and NH3 catalytic oxidation on Cu0.005Ti-Ice catalysts reduced N2O and NO2 concentration, resulting in outstanding SCR activity at low temperature.
coredata.dc:title: Superior performance of Cu/TiO2 catalyst prepared by ice melting method for low-temperature selective catalytic reduction of NOx by NH3
